title: 112_hr2867
content: The Act is titled the "United States Commission on International Religious Freedom Reform and Reauthorization Act of 2011." It establishes that each member of the Commission shall serve a 2-year term and may not serve more than 2 terms. The Act limits members of the Commission to serving 2 terms and specifies that if a member attends less than 75% of meetings during a term, they are ineligible for reappointment. The International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 limits Commission members to two terms and prohibits reappointment if attendance falls below 75%. Additionally, members are ineligible for a second consecutive term as Chair and must adhere to federal travel regulations. The International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 limits Commission members to two terms, prohibits reappointment for low attendance, and enforces adherence to federal travel regulations. Additionally, antidiscrimination laws are applied for addressing violations related to employment, family leave, fair labor standards, and employee polygraph. The Commission's employees are to be treated as Senate or House employees for the application of antidiscrimination laws related to various employment rights and protections. Employees of the Commission are to be treated as Senate or House employees for antidiscrimination laws. Any pending claims can be maintained under the International Religious Freedom Act. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2012 through 2014 is amended. Standards of conduct and disclosure under the Act are also amended. SEC. 5 amends the International Religious Freedom Act by increasing the financial limit and changing the department name. SEC. 6 changes the termination date. SEC. 7 requires a report on the Act's implementation within a year of enactment. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report on the implementation of the Act and its amendments within a year of enactment. The report will review the effectiveness of US Government programs promoting international religious freedom and assess the Office on International Religious Freedom's roles and functions. The report will assess the roles and functions of the Office on International Religious Freedom, the Ambassador at Large for International Religious Freedom, and the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom. It will also compare the structure of the Commission with other offices in the Department of State. The curr_chunk discusses the establishment of the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom and includes a comparative analysis of its structure with other advisory commissions. It also reviews the relationship between the Ambassador at Large for International Religious Freedom and the Commission, suggesting possible reforms. The term "appropriate congressional committees" is defined in this section. The curr_chunk discusses the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
